title: 112_hr924
content: The "Jobs for Veterans Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of this Act. It includes a program for veterans called the Veterans Business Center Program. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a Veterans Business Center Program to provide entrepreneurial training and counseling to veterans. A Director will be appointed to oversee the program. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a Veterans Business Center Program for entrepreneurial training and counseling for veterans. The Director may appoint regional coordinators to oversee veterans business centers and designate entities through a process for funding grants. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a Veterans Business Center Program for entrepreneurial training and counseling for veterans. The Director may appoint regional coordinators to oversee veterans business centers and designate entities through a process for funding grants. The Director can provide initial grants of $200,000 each year for up to 5 years to veterans business centers. After receiving 5 years of initial grants, centers can receive growth funding grants of $150,000 each year for up to 3 years, with performance benchmarks required for eligibility in subsequent years. Each veterans business center funded under the Veterans Business Center Program is responsible for veteran entrepreneurial development, counseling, and government procurement assistance. Centers must provide a 50% non-Federal match for the funds received, with the option for a waiver based on hardship. The Director prioritizes applications for veterans business centers in areas with low income and high unemployment rates. Priority is given to areas without existing centers and with a high population of veterans, especially from recent military operations. New Dawn exceeds the national median of such measure. The Director shall develop an annual training program for staff of veterans business centers in consultation with various organizations. The authority of section 8(b)(17) designates centers receiving funds from the National Veterans Business Development Corporation as veterans business centers eligible for grants. The Director must report annually on veterans' access in rural areas and prioritize improvements if necessary. During the one-year period after the report submission, priority will be given to applications for grants to establish veterans business centers in rural areas. $12,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2012 and $14,000,000 for fiscal year 2013. The Director of the Veterans Business Center program will establish a grant program for access to capital for designated veterans business centers. The grants aim to assist veteran-owned small businesses in securing capital, repairing credit, providing seminars on securing loans, offering financial counseling, facilitating access to financing sources, and improving financial presentations to lenders. The Director may award grants to veterans business centers for counseling small business owners who are reserve component members of the Armed Forces and developing programs to help unemployed veterans become entrepreneurs. The maximum grant amount per center is $75,000. The Director is authorized to appropriate $1,500,000 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for a procurement assistance grant program to help veteran-owned small businesses identify suitable contracts and prepare to be subcontractors or prime contractors. The Director may award grants to veteran-owned small businesses for training, business advisement, and technical assistance with Federal procurement processes. The maximum grant amount per veterans business center is $75,000. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. The Director is authorized to establish a grant program for service-disabled veteran-owned small businesses, with $1,500,000 authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. Grants are provided for outreach programs and training in business development for service-disabled veterans. The Director may award grants up to $75,000 to veterans business centers for development, marketing, budgeting, accounting, and merchandising assistance. Additionally, there is an authorization of $1,500,000 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for the Veterans Entrepreneurial Development Summit held every 2 years to provide networking opportunities. The Director may award grants to veterans business centers for various assistance. There is an authorization of $450,000 for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for events providing networking opportunities and education for veterans. Surviving spouses of Armed Forces members are included in the definition of "veteran". The term "veteran-owned small business" includes businesses owned by surviving spouses of Armed Forces members and veterans, as well as members of the reserve components of the Armed Forces. The Small Business Act is amended to require biannual reporting on interagency task force appointments and activities. Additionally, the Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of the Act on small businesses owned by veterans, providing recommendations for more effective implementation.
